thread.title: EU vote too close to call in North East, Journal poll reveals
thread.title_full: EU vote too close to call in North East, Journal poll reveals

author: Graeme Whitfield
title: EU vote too close to call in North East, Journal poll reveals
text:
EU vote too close to call in North East, Journal poll reveals 04:00, 3 Jun 2016 Journal poll conducted by Hexham pollsters Panelbase puts the Leave campaign in a narrow lead Shares Comments Get business news by email A European Union referendum postal voting form waits to be signed on June 1, 2016 in Knutsford, United Kingdom 
The EU referendum vote is too close to call in the North East, a poll commissioned by The Journal suggests. 
A survey of just over 500 people carried out by Hexham-based polling company Panelbase found that 50% of those likely to vote in the referendum wanted to leave the EU while 43% wanted to remain in. 
But 7% of those questioned were still undecided, suggesting that both sides of the debate could still win the referendum on June 23. 
The poll also showed that immigration is - by a small degree - the main issue likely to affect people’s votes, with 31% of those questioned highlighting that as their major concern. Those highlighting immigration were more likely to vote for Brexit. 
But the economy (27%) and the UK’s place in the world (23%) were also cited as reasons for voting, with people highlighting both of those issues more likely to want to stay in the EU . 
The Journal/Panelbase poll also showed how age is likely to affect people’s vote in the referendum, with the Remain side well ahead (by 61% to 32%) in the 18-34 age range, but behind in the 34-55 group (by 51% to 40%) and substantially behind (61% to 34%) in the 55+ age range. 
When asked on whether they would vote, people wanting to leave the EU were slightly more likely to say they would definitely vote on June 23, but not by a large margin. 
Steve Turner, Vote Leave regional director, said: “The North East stands to gain so much when we Vote Leave. We can be a more outward looking region with the means to invest in our own priorities, increase trade outside of the EU and recruit the skilled people we need to grow our industries. 
“The social and economic costs of the EU model are holding our region back from achieving its potential in the world.” 
But Guy Opperman, Hexham MP and a Remain campaigner, said: “Polls go up and polls go down. The fact of the matter is that we are fighting for every single vote in this referendum. 
“It is vital for the North East that we secure a Remain vote on June 23 because the stakes could not be higher. The highly-respected Institute for Fiscal Studies found that leaving Europe would leave a £40bn black hole in the public purse while HM Treasury estimates that 20,000 jobs in the North East would be lost. 
“Vote Leave has not made a compelling case on the economy and we know that a British exit from the world’s largest trading bloc would mean taking a dangerous path, for the UK’s finances and for the future of this region.” 
The Journal/Panelbase poll is being published with three weeks to go until the referendum. 
Campaigning yesterday saw Prime Minister David Cameron highlighting the environmental benefits of remaining in the EU while a group of prominent artists, including Angel of the North sculptor Antony Gormley, issued art works backing the Remain side. 
But Vote Leave campaigners were again highlighting concerns around immigration while one of their chief economists attempted to challenge claims that Brexit would harm the economy. 
Those surveyed in The Journal/Panelbase poll thought the country would be better able to handle terrorism and climate change if it stayed in the union. 
But they thought the economy, immigration and the refugee crisis would be better handled if the country voted to go it alone. 
The results of the poll were based on online responses from 505 people in the North East weighted for age and gender to be representative of the population nationally. It was carried out by Hexham-based Panelbase.
